title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [24 march 1873]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [24 March 1873]
text: mondayMonday afternoon My dear waltWaltas i am here in the sellensalon or dining room as its called as i am alone and no one to talk to i thought i would write to you as i am scant of paper i will write on two scraps i have picked up i received your letter this forenoon i dontdon't get hardly any letters except yours i suppose i should get quite a corresspondencecorrespondence if i answered all the letters i have got since you have been sick) and i have received several concerning poor mattysMatty's death i got a letter the other day that frighenedfrightened me it was from st louisSt. Louis i opened it and the first words i saw was dear madam dontdon't be surprised at being addressed by a stranger the first thought i had was that jeffJeff or the children had been attacked with that deseasedisease that has been so fatal in st louisSt. Louis the spinal disease but it proved to be a letter from one of matteesMattie's dear freendsfriends she spoke much of the children she said hattieHattie was a very remarkable child and little JesseeJesse was very fat and well and said how much mattyMatty talked about me and a very nice letter it was indeedJust after Mattie's death Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [24 March 1873]
